comment.narrative: 1. No comprehensive institutional agreements among source and inventory leads 2. Limited awareness and capacity on NAMAs

1. National Green House Gas Inventory Management System Strengthened. 2. National Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs) developed. 3. Monitoring Reporting and Verfification system (MRV) for approved NAMAs in place

Status as of 7 December, 2016; 1. The physical aspect (IT) of the system has been procured and delivered to the relevant agencies and the draft GHG data collection protocal has been reviewed and accepted. 2.Four NAMA proposals on small hydro, sustainable charcoal production, and sustainable agriculture and integrated waste management have been developed 3.The MRVs for the four NAMAS have been developed

description.narrative: % of GBV cases resulting in convictions % of GBV cases addressed through formal court system %of people in surveyed communities aged 18yrs and above that have received information on GBV. Amount of resources leveraged from state and non-state partners participating in the implementation of the GBV programme

comment.narrative: 10% (2008) of reported GBV cases resulting in convivctions 32% (2010) of GBV cases addressed through the formal court system 51.7% of people in surveyed communities aged 18yrs and above have received information on GBV. Zero ZMK leveraged from State and Non-ste partners participating in the implementation of the GBV Programme

(i) Zambia Police Sexual and Gender Based Violence crimes databse established (ii) Ten Village led GBV One Stop Centers established (iii) One GBV Shelter established in Kabwe to support the Fast Track Court (iv) 300 local and traditional court adjudicators trained.

(i) The Zambia Police Sexual and Gender Based Violence databse has been established and the crime reporting occurance book had been made electronic. (ii) Eleven Village led One Stop Centers were established in four provinces of Zambia namely; Eastern, Lusaka, Central and Western.This has resulted in 1,200 GBV cases that have been reported by the communities, in these villages, and addressed by the police. (iii) Works on establishing a GBV shelter in the Central Province of Zambia, where the Kabwe GBV Fast Track Court has commenced. (iv) 204 customary court adjudicators that included headwomen and headmen who preside over cases at village level, as well as local court magistrates and local court officers were trained in adjudicating GBV cases in conformity with CEDAW, so that customary court adjudicators desist from enforcing customary practices that exacerbate GBV .

title.narrative: Zambia Technical Facility for Strategic Response to GRZ

description.narrative: The Zambia Technical Facility for Strategic Response to Government of Zambia 2012-2015 is aimed at enhancing the attainment of the national development results embodied in the GRZs SNDP and the UNDP/GRZ CPAP.

title.narrative: Zambia Technical Facility for Strategic Response to the Government of Zambia 2012 - 2015
INDIVIUDAL CONSULTANTS PROCUREMENT NOTICE - Consultancy to Develop Guidelines and Procedures for a Comprehensive Framework for Public Investment Planning, Appraisal and Management for Zambia

description.narrative: The Zambia Technical Facility for Strategic Response to Government of Zambia 2012-2015 is aimed at enhancing the attainment of the national development results embodied in the GRZs SNDP and the UNDP/GRZ CPAP.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

1. MDG Acceleration Plan focusing on poverty and unemployment; 2013 MDG Progress Report for Zambia; and 2013 Zambia Human Development Report.
2. National Accounts, Input-Output and Social Accounting Matrices with gender disaggregated data and environment accounting systems.
3. Database of viable, bankable and affordable appraised public investment projects.

comment.narrative:
1. The country has no MDG Acceleration Plan focusing on poverty and unemployment; 2011 MDG Progress Report for Zambia exists and will be updated to include current development trends; and 2011 Zambia Human Development Report exists and will be updated to show current HDI for Zambia.
2. National Accounts, Input-Output and Social Accounting Matrices does not include gender disaggregated data and environment accounting systems.
3. The country does not have a database of viable, bankable and affordable appraised public investment projects.

1. 2015 Comprehensive MDG Progress Report is Produced 2. 2016 Zambia National Human Development Report is produced and disseminated in all 10 provinces 3. Guides and Standard Operating Procedures for the Project Appraisal System at the Ministry of Finance Developed 4. The Seventh National Development Plan which has mainstreamed SDGs is produced by the Ministry of Finance

1. The Draft 2015 Comprehensive MDG Progress Report has been produced and validated with broad stakeholder consultation through out the process. The report is being finalised (editing and layout) for printing and expected to the launched early in 2016.
2. The 2016 Zambia National Human Development Report with the theme " Industrialisation and Human Development: Poverty Reduction through Employment and Wealth Creation" was produced and launched on 10th May 2016 in Lusaka. It was also disseminated through stakeholder consultations health in five other provinces (Central, Copperbelt, North-Western, Eastern and Southern)
3. Guidelines and Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the Project Appraisal System has now been moved to the Ministry of National Development Planning were developed and adopted.
4. UNDP held provincial consultation the Private Sector and Civil Society Organisations on SDGs. UNDP also supported the mainstreaming of SDGs through Co-Charing with the Ministry of National Development Planning, the Government and UN Technical Working group on the preparation of the Seventh National Development Plan. The SDG Prioritisation and mainstreaming workshop which was supposed to be held in 2016 with the support of the Regional Service centre will take place in January 2017.

title.narrative: Promotion of Women's and Children's Rights

description.narrative: This programme has a goal to promote and protect the rights of women and children and to reduce the gender imbalances in the social, political and economic spheres of Zambia

title.narrative: Ministry of Gender and Child Development
Programme for the Promotion and Protection of Womens and Childrens Rights

description.narrative: The programme goal is to contribute to the promotion and protection of women and children's rights in Zambia and to reduced gender imbalances in the social, political and economic spheres in the country.
capital of a political entity
capital of a political entity

Strategy to review and revise laws to conform to CEDAW provisions developed
Strategy implemented to to increase women's land ownership
Committee of Permanent Secretaries Established to implement the engendering public service strategy

comment.narrative:
Gender Inequality Index -0.627
Number of Laws revised to conform to CEDAW provisions - 0 % of newly allocated state land 20% % of women in decision making positions in civil service Permanent Secretary - 19% Director - 23% Deputy Director - 43%

(i) Strategy for increasing women representation in politics implemented. (ii) Implementation plan for the gender provisions of the new Constitution developed (iii)Gender Responsive budgeting institutionalized in 7 line ministries (iv) 2014 Gender Status Report produced.

(i)The Count Her in Strategy aimed at having at least 50 percent representation of female candidates was implemented. One political party (PF) set a target of having women comprise 40% of its adopted candidates. After the August elections, more women MPs and Councillors were elected in 2016 than in 2011 (26 female MPs elected in 2016 against the 17 elected in 2011 and 127 women councilors elected in 2016 against the 85 elected in 2011). (ii) Consultations on the implementation plan for the gender provisions of the new Consitution commenced and the TORS for the Gender Equity and Equality Commission Structure were developed. (iii)15Line Ministries have operationalized gender responsive budgeting tools, 9 out of the 15 line ministries have gender-responsivee budgets; whilst 12 Line ministries are reflecting expenditures on gender. (iv) The 2014 Gender Status Report was produced. It is an update of the 2011 Baseline Report and is a reflection of the progress being made towards attaining gender equity and equality as measured by the indicators set out in the National Monitoring and Evaluation Plan 2010-2015. The report measures the progress in relation to the 2011 Baseline with regard to the causes, effects, impacts and possible mitigation measures in key areas including education, health, decision - making, skills and economic participation

title.narrative: Strengthening climate information and early warning syst

description.narrative: Strengthening climate information and early warning systems in Zambia for climate resilient development and adaptation to climate change

title.narrative: Early Warning Systems Project 2014 Initial Annual Work Plan

description.narrative: Strengthening climate information and early warning systems in Zambia for climate resilient development and adaptation to climate change
second-order administrative division
second-order administrative division
second-order administrative division
1. Score of the capacity assessment as per scorecard 2. number of automatic and manual weather instruments procured, installed and functional.

comment.narrative: 1. Capacity scorecard rating of 80 across men and women (includes functional capacities for agencies to both monitor and forecast climate-related hazard information, share and package such information with relevant agencies, disseminate both warnings and advisories based on such information and provide appropriate legal and procedural frameworks) 2. 0 automatic weather station and 0 manual instruments in the targeted districts

1. 41 existing manual monitoring stations procured and rehabilitated 2.Review and and install appropriate telecommunication infrastructure to establish connectivity to all procured automatic weather stations to strengthen Zambia Meteorological Department's capacity to monitor and forecast climate information. 3. Procure and install equipment including hardware required for modern meteorological forecasting workstations 4. Conduct training for Weather Forecasters on MESSIR-COM (software that provides accurate weather predictions and issues warnings about severe weather conditions) to provide upper air monitoring ascent measurements

1. All 41 manual weather stations rehabilitated and capacity to monitor and forecast extreme weather events enhanced through the upgraded systems 2.Telecommunications infrastructure procured and installed and capacity to monitor and forecast weather information increased 3. Forecasting workstations upgraded with uninterrupted observation of climate and weather information 4.Technical capacity of ZMD developed though training to improve the production of standard and customized weather and climate forecasts

1.Procure and install 100 automatic rain gauges in selected priority districts including solar panels, batteries and general packet radio modems for data transmission. 2. Develop and establish an online climate map room for agriculture, water, energy, health and disaster risk reduction products and services with a link to Zambia Meteorological climate information web based system 3.Undertake a Socio-economic benefit analysis of climate information to the agriculture, water, energy, health and disaster risk reduction 4.Develop and establish an early warning computing systems, with dissemination/transmission system 5. Establish a publish a public-private partnership between an interested private sector entity and Zambia Meteorological Department. This will include establishment of SOPs and agreement to allow the private sector company to use the data generated by the meteorological observation network for the purpose of selling products

description.narrative: To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Zambia

1 Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard
2 Domestic finance committed to ZMD and DMMU to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change

comment.narrative:
1 Average capacity scorecard rating of 80 across men and women see Annex 5 of project document
2 Annual budget of US322680 allocated to ZMD and US614057 allocated to DMMU

1 Capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 171 for both men and women see Annex 5 of project document
2 20 increase in annual domestic finance allocated to ZMD and DMMU to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change

This development objective is ontrack There has been capacity enhancement in climate information generation packaging and dissemination since the project commenced
1 ZMDs capacity score has increased from 80 to 105 out of 171 This has been achieved through training of staff of the implementing entities Eight officers from the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock MAL who were managing weather stations without any formal training in meteorology have been trained in meteorological observation and interpretation and are therefore now able to interpret and simplify weather information for use by local farming communities Twentytwo officers from the Zambia Meteorological Department ZMD have undergone a refresher course in meteorological codes compiling of climate information and packaging of weather and climate information This has improved capacities for climate information production packaging and dissemination at district level Also twenty officers from ZMD were trained as enumerators for the CIEWS national baseline survey This enumeration course empowered the meteorological staff to engage with communities on the application of climate information This has contributed to the staff providing and interpreting weather information for use by local communities which they in turn are using to plan their livelihood activities such as farming and fishing Thirty ZMD staff have received training in software applications that will enable them to improve data management at the weather stations and they have also been provided with new highcapacity computer hardware Furthermore ZMD has benefited from two advisor missions during the period under review The first mission was by the CIRDA Chief Technical Advisor on Alternative Technologies who built ZMDs capacity in Early Warning System design The second mission was by the UNDP RSC Programme Specialist for Disaster Risk Reduction and Climate Change who collaborated with ZMD to assess the equipment and staffing requirements for data rescue
2 There has been a 50 increase in domestic finance allocated to ZMD for early warning systems in the period under review from a budget of 322680 USD in the baseline year This is due to advocacy by ZMD and the Disaster Management and Mitigation Unit DMMU on the importance of early warning systems to safeguard lives livelihoods property and infrastructure

description.narrative: Efficient and effective use of hydrometeorological and environmental information for making early warnings and longterm development plans

1 Percentage of population in Chipata Gwembe and Sesheke Districts with access to improved climaterelated flood and drought warnings disaggregated by gender
2 Development frameworks and disaster policies that integrate climate information in the formulation
3 Sectorspecific tailored climate information packages that integrate climate risks

comment.narrative:
1 0 of men
0 of women
2 The Sixth National Development Plan highlights the need to develop climate change mainstreaming and response strategies but not the need for improved information to inform the strategies
3 ZMD in collaboration with the relevant line ministries produces sectorspecific forecasts for agriculture aviation water and health

1 100 of men
100 of women
2 At least the Seventh National Development Plan to incorporate the availability of climate information into planning for the five year period
3 Sectorspecific tailored climate information packages produced for agriculture aviation water health tourism construction road and rail transport and energy

This outcome is ontrack
1 At the start of the project there was minimal evidence of application of hydrological meteorological and environmental information by individual Zambians in their livelihood activities The CIEWS project has conducted awarenessraising activities in the three CIEWS pilot districts ten other climatevulnerable districts and the ten provincial capitals Preliminary results from a recent national survey conducted by the CIEWS project has revealed that approximately 30 of those surveyed in 30 districts across the country now apply weather and climate information in planning their livelihood activities particularly fishing and farming This information is disseminated to them through radio television print media and the internet The project has contributed to enhancing public information on climate change as well as enhanced capacity of ZMD for web management so that uptodate weather information is made available to the general public For further information see wwwzmdgovzm A CIEWS project brochure is also available on this website
2 The Seventh National Development Plan is under development and its theme will be inclusive green growth in recognition of the impacts of climate change Currently there is training for planners in all vulnerable key sectors on climate change mainstreaming and national adaptation planning
3 ZMD is providing more timely and accurate tailored information to the aviation sector daily flight forecasts and agricultural sector 10day crop weather bulletins available on ZMD website wwwzmdgovzm and distributed to farmers Tailored information for agriculture has contributed to the small scale farmers receiving appropriate information in good time to be used for planning For other sectors tailored information is provided on request This has been enabled through institutional strengthening by providing modern equipment and training

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity of Zambia Meteorological Department to monitor and forecast extreme weather and climate change

1 Percentage of national coverage of climate monitoring network fully operational
2 Frequency data transmission and reception

comment.narrative:
1 Automatic 0 of districts Manual 0 of districts
2 At present the 2 AWSs transmit data which is sent daily
The majority of manual stations record data at GMT 06h00 09h00 12h00 15h00 However provision to ZMD does not occur daily

1 Automatic 29 of districts
Manual 37 of districts
2 30 AWSs 28 new 2 rehabilitated transmitting continuously
39 rehabilitated manual stations collecting data at the synoptic hours of GMT 06h00 09h00 12h00 15h00 18h00 and 00h00 and sending to ZMD daily

This outcome is ontrack
1 At the start of the project Zambia Meteorological Department had a network of 39 manual weather stations that were each missing some instruments and two automatic weather stations that had been vandalized The manual weather stations are to be rehabilitated in the second half of 2015 as the instruments are under procurement The target of 29 of districts having automatic weather stations has already been exceeded as 19 stations have been installed through cofinancing from the Southern African Science Service Centre for Climate Change and Adaptive Land Use SASSCAL 5 through cofinancing from the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa COMESA and 8 by the UNDPGEF Climate Change Adaptation project with the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Thus the network of automatic weather stations has expanded from 2 to 32 This brings the current percentage of districts having automatic weather stations to 31 This will be increased further to 58 with the installation of 28 additional automatic weather stations by the CIEWS project in the second half of 2015 as the equipment is under procurement
2 This modernization of the observing network has enabled realtime observation of current weather conditions Timeliness of data transmission and exchange has been improved as the automatic weather stations provide data at 15minute intervals 24 hours per day Furthermore the accuracy of weather forecasts has been enhanced

title.narrative: UN Joint Programme on Climate Change and Disaster Risk Reduction
REPORT OF 1ST AND 2ND QUARTER ACTIVITIES REVIEW OF ENVIRONMENT PROJECTS

description.narrative: The government and partners adhere to revised and harmonised policy, legal and regulatory frameworks for coordinating the response to climate change in agriculture, forestry, energy, industry and water sectors
capital of a political entity
1. Policies and legal frameworks for agriculture, forestry and land take into account climate change issues 2. NAP and NAMAs foragriculture, energy, industry and waste management sectors in place

comment.narrative: 1. The Draft Forest Policy has been reviewed to take into account climate change but the Act has not been reviewed 2.The draft NCCRS, but not its implementation plans have been developed 3. The CCFU has been the interim mechanism for coordinating climate change adaption and mitigation efforts

The targets for 2016 are; 1. conduct provincial stakeholders meeting to sensitize stakeholders on INDC and prioritize programs to be implemented under INDC 2.develop INDC implementation plan 3. conduct evaluation for the UNREDD programme 4.Develop Health National Adaptation Plan

1. Provincial meetings conducted and priority programmes identified and prioritized. 2.UNREDD evaluation conducted and management response prepared by all the implementing agencies and government 3.consultant recruited to develop the Health National Adaptation Plan. The inception report has since been submitted for review.

The targets for 2017 are: 1. Finalize the Health National Adaptation Plan 2. Develop National Determined Contribution (NDC)Investment Plan 3. Develop the implementation plan of National Policy on Climate Change

1. Gap analysis for the health sector developed through a consultative process in all the provinces. The report will be validated by stakeholders in 2018 2. Provincial consultations conducted in all the provinces to support the development of the NDC investment plan. In addition the Zambia Environmental Management Agency is in the process of recruiting the consultant to support the process of developing the investment plan 3. stakeholders meeting held to develop and cost the implementation plan. However, this activity was not completed due to lack of some specialists. The process will be completed in 2018
1. Terminal evaluation of project

title.narrative: Mid-Term Evaluation of the Strengthening Management Effectiveness and Generating Multiple Environmental Benefits within and around the Greater Kafue National Park and West Lunga National Park in Zambia Final Evaluation of the promoting Innovative, Inclusi

description.narrative: PIMS4625 Strengthening Management and Generating Multiple Environment Benefits Within and Around the Greater Kafue National Park and West Lunga National Park in Zambia
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Kafue National Park and West Lunga Game Management Areas, Zambia

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

Sustainable Land and Forest Management established in Miombo Woodland and Dry Evergreen Forest ecosystems in Protected Area (PA) Core areas and Community managed Game Management Areas (GMAs) and conservancies enabling forest corridor connectivity between West Lunga National Park (WLNP) and Kfue National Park (KNP) in the long term

comment.narrative: Biodiversity and carbon sinks of Kafue/West Lunga in Zambia are better protected from threats and effectively managed by local institutions, communities, and economic actors using sustainable forestry and land management practices

1. Strategy for improved management effectiveness and increased revenues of Kafue National and West Lunga National Parks finalised. 2. 25 officers trained in law enforcement administration. 3. 400 farmers in 10 VAGs engaged in conservation farming covering 1,200 Ha. 4. 15 VAGs develop land use plans.

1.The Draft Strategy has been prepared 2.The consultant conducting the Law Enforcement Consultancy is underway. Training will be done after it has been completed. 3. 1,567 (661 (females and 906 males) farmers in 25 VAGs trained in conservation farming. 58 lead farmers have been been engaged to commence activities, with the onset of the rainy season. Information on the Ha covered will be available in the first quarter 2017, after monitoring has been conducted. 4. 6 VAGs develop land use plans. The remaining land use plans will be developed in 2017

description.narrative: Biodiversity and carbon sinks of Greater Kafue West Lunga in Zambia are better protected from threats and effectively managed by local institutions communities and economic actors using sustainable forestry and land management practices

Sustainable Land and Forest Management established in Miombo Woodland and Dry Evergreen Forest ecosystems in PA Core areas and Community managed GMAs and conservancies enabling forest corridor connectivity between WLNP and KNP in the long term

comment.narrative:
24164 km2
PA Core areas

24164 km2 PA 41297 km2 GMAs
65461 km2
Target GMAs consisting of Mumbwa Namwala Mufunta KasonsoBusanga and LungaLuswishi in Greater Kafue NP and Lukwawa Musele Matembo and ChibwikaNtambu in West Lunga Management Area

This development target is on course so far Kafue National Park KNP 22480 sq km and West Lunga National Park WLNP1684 sq km in terms of initial efforts to put in place an effective system to remove threats such as poaching and protecting the biodiversity This has been through enhanced law enforcement fire management research to manage the carnivores infrastructure development to support law enforcement tourism and monitoring This has contributed to the increase in animal population particularly the elephants and buffalos KNP Annual Report 2014 In WLNP a similar situation has occurred where more elephant and buffalo sighting have been reported WLNP Ecological Monitoring Report 2014 Furthermore WLNP and Lukwakwa GMA have been designated as an Important Bird Area Birdlife International 2014 The project contribution has been mainly through community awareness raising activities on the need to conserve the natural resources and remove the threats to biodiversity
Regarding the Game Management Areas MuseleMateboChibwikaNtambo and Lukwakwa Kasonso Busanga Lunga Luswishi comprising a total area of 28910 square km against the target of 41297 square km have been brought under improved management This comprises 70 of the targeted area The improved management has been through strengthening the Community Based Natural Resources Management CBNRM through the village scouts and promoting sustainable livelihoods fish farming beekeeping conservation farming and agro forestry This has contributed to improved resources management and communities are in the process of establishing the conservancies in open areas
The contribution of the project was through strengthening CBNRM

Sustainable land and forest management by the communities is progressing though at a low rate So far 188128 ha in Sanje Local Forest in Mumbwa and Lunda National Forest in Mwinilunga are being managed sustainably with the involvement of local communities against the target of 557900 ha This is 34 of the target The promoting sustainable livelihoods beekeeping and conservation farming tree planting and sustainable utilisation of the forest products and enhanced law enforcement North Western and Central Province Provincial Forest Reports 2014

description.narrative:
2 Conservation farming practices applied in targeted GMAs
Increased yields

comment.narrative: 0 ha using conservation farming techniques

At least 3760 ha of conservation farming practiced by at least 1600 HH in 40 VAGs by end of project
Introduction of conservation farming practices leads to improved soil organic matter and field intensification across 3760 hectares leading to
40 reduction in cumulative CO2 emissions from vegetation clearance for agriculture in targeted areas resulting in 7520 ha of avoided deforestation in targeted areas
Resulting decrease in direct lifetime avoided t CO2 emissions from clearance of vegetation for agriculture 20 years in that same landscape 988128 tCO2e compared to BAU scenario

This target is on course Communities in West Lunga game management areas have been mobilized sensitized and oriented in conservation farming So far 500 against the target of 1600 households in 2014205 farming season are practicing conservation farming This presents 31 of the target The productivity of maize for those farmers who are practicing conservation farming have increased from 2 tonnes per hectare to 8 tonnes per hectare per year

description.narrative: 3 Demonstration of avoided deforestation no net loss in at least 25 VAGs establishing REDD pilots linking to national andor voluntary carbon financing

comment.narrative: 0 ha no REDD pilots in VAGs

25000 ha leveraging additional 75000 ha intact forest by protecting VAG designated forest zones
VCS and CCB standard acceptable to international brokers certifying REDD pilots and marketing for carbon financing
Potential buyers identified to purchase the REDD carbon credits from the VAG pilots
No change The activities have not taken place the have been planned for subsequent quarters

description.narrative: 4 Reduced rate of deforestation from fuel wood extraction in all targeted GMAs

comment.narrative:
Unsustainable firewood collection and SFM governance
Wood fuel collection in designated areas is adhoc and unsustainable
No sustainable woodlots exist in targeted areas
Knowledge of coppicing practices for fuel wood extraction among communities in targeted areas is very low

Under the project designated zones for fuel wood collection will be established optimizing SFM and testing different treatments
Working with the Copperbelt University the 25 VAGs will be trained in harvesting and coppice management and will each establish an auditable fuel wood use and CFM plan
Linked to land use planning experimental fuel wood management and collection zones will be established in 25 VAGs systems boundaries for VAGs will be defined and alternative operational modalities for fuel wood harvesting and use will be applied including coppicing
Leading to the following GEBs
Direct lifetime avoided emissions savings of 63281 tCO2e 20 years compared to fuel wood usage in a BAU scenario
There has been no change as the project focus in the reporting period was on sensitization The next step would be engaging the communities in the development of land use plans

description.narrative: 5 Reduced rate of deforestation from late season fires in targeted GMA zones

comment.narrative:
Late season fires and poor fire management monitoring and practices in all targeted GMA zones
174671 ha of forests burned in lateseason fires annually in GMA areas in KNP
627088 ha of forests burned in lateseason fires annually in PA zones of KNP
Annual estimated CO2 emissions from fire in GMA zones of KNP 230566 tCO2e per annum
Annual estimated CO2 emissions from fire in PA parts of KNP 827756 tCO2e per annum

Land use and forest conservation plans will be developed and adopted by all VAGs supported and monitored by Kafue Central Business Unit CBU
Forest and wildlife patrolling and protection will be done by Village Scouts in all targeted GMAs
Fire control action plans will be adopted and put in use in all VAGs
As a result fire losses will be reduced by at least 30 in GMA zones annually through fire protection practices boundary and firebreak management early burning etc land use planning patrolling and education
The resulting direct lifetime avoided t CO2 emissions over 20 years from these activities compared to a BAU scenario in GMA zones 1383394 tCO2e

There has been no change as the project focus in the reporting period was on sensitization The next step would be engaging the communities in undertaking fire management through the Village Actions Groups

title.narrative: Promoting Communit Based Climate Resilient Forest Regen

description.narrative: The objective of the project is to enhance climate resilience of ecosystems through Assisted Natural Regeneration (ANR), Agroforestry and Integrated Fire Management and enhancing energy and resource use efficiency.

Reducing the vulnerability of local communities to the effects of climate change by enhancing the capacity of Forest Department and local communities to plan for climate change and implementing adaptation measures.
second-order administrative division
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1 15,000 hactres brought under natural or assisted regeneration. 2 Fire management plans developed and implemented in targeted areas. 3 2000 community members mobilized, trained and are involved in community based natural resource management.

comment.narrative: 1. 0 hectares of regenerated forest 2. 1limited capacity in fire monitoring (no fire management plan in place) 3. limited capacity in community based natural resource management (no communities involved in natural resources management)

1. select 15,000 hacters of land in Serenje and Chitambo for assisted natural regeneration 2. Strengthen the capacity of district forest officers in natural resource management 3. strengthen the capacity of community to manage natural resources

1. 27,000 hacters of land set aside for forest regeneration 2. Forest department officers from 11 districts in Central province trained on community based natural resource management. 3. community members in Serenje and Chitambo trained setting up tree nurseries and resource mapping

1. Formation and registration of 30 village action groups in Serenje and Chitambo Districts in Central province 2. opening of boundary and zoning of Assisted Natural Regeneration sites 3. Validation of the resource and land use maps for the pilot sites 4.Map historical trends of fire incidence and burn severity in central province 5. Develop fire management plans for the five pilot sites( Musangashi, Musola, Nakatambo, Teta and Mweshe Butela)

1. 30 village action groups formed and registered as associations. The associations will be registered as community forest management committees as per the Forest Policy. 2. Opening of boundary and zoning of ANR sites completed for ( Musangashi, Musola, Nakatambo, Teta and Mweshe Butela). The opening of boundary was done through cash for work principles as provided for in the labour policy. 3.resource maps for the pilot sites developed. 4. report on historical trends of fire incidence and burn severity developed by the consultant.In addition a fire occurrence database has been established at the Forestry Department Headquarters in Lusaka which form an integral part of the draft fire management plans 5.village action group members, forest department, chiefs representative and other stakeholders capacity strengthened to develop the fire management plans for the 5 pilot sites. 6. Fire management and maintenance schedules for the 5 pilot sites developed

1. Establishment of fire breaks in Serenje and Chitambo Districts 2. Livelihood activities like bee keeping, mushrooming growing, small livestock undertaken across the 32 Village Action Groups in Serenje and Chitambo Districts 3. Agroforestry and assisted natural regeneration activities undertaken across 10,000 hacteres in Serenje and Chitambo Districts 4. Energy efficient technologies piloted across the 10 efficient charcoal producer groups

description.narrative: a) Average cost of elections per registered voter during elections b) Percentage of registered voters voting in elections (Voter turnout)

comment.narrative: 2016 General Elections (entire process including nominations, results management) held under amended electoral laws in line with the New Constitution.

UNDP supported the Electoral Commission of Zambia in collaboration with the Ministry of Justice to review relevant legal frameworks and in turn aligned these to the new Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Act No. 2 of 2016. Support included the drafting, enactment and implementation of the Electoral Commission of Zambia Act No. 25 of 2016 and the Electoral Process Act No. 35 of 2016. As a result, the ECZ on 9 July 2016 invoked one of its new powers under the new Electoral Commission Act (Sub-section 28-2) resulting in the suspension of all political campaigning in Lusaka and Namwala for 10 days after clashes, therefore expanding a balanced playing field and participation of political players. Further, the Local Government Election Tribunals were operationalized to handle local government petitions within 30 days through support rendered on the training of 54 Tribunal Members. This included magistrates, lawyers and court clerks.
ECZ supported to develop an implementation plan for recommendations from the 2016 General Elections
Strategic Plan (2016-2020) integrated with lessons learnt from 2016 General Elections and Referendum

comment.narrative: 2014-2016 Strategic Framework for Local Integration of former refugees in Zambia 2016 Resettlement Policy 6th National Development Plan 2016 - 2021 UN-GRZ Sustainable Development Partnership Framework

1. Functional Project coordination and management structures in place 2. Project Coordination framework implemented 3. Resettlement communities are well-established and connected to neighbouring settlement areas 4. Access to social services and sustainable economic opportunities 5. Communities have access to safe water and improved sanitation facilities

1.Two national UNVs were recruited and placed in Meheba and Mayukwayukwa as Scheme Coordinators under the Department of Resettlement. DDCC meetings were held in March in Kalumbila and Kaoma districts. 2. GRZ coordination offices were established in both locations. IT equipment, including office supplies and furniture were facilitated to ensure GRZ coordination of the programme. Transport (motorcyles) were facilitated to ensure project coordination. 3. 20km of access roads in Meheba completed, connecting the resettlement scheme with surrounding communities 4. With opening up of access roads, access to social services was facilitated. Tractors have been procured and will be delivered in Dec. 2017 to ease farming activities and facilitate access to markets. 5. 38 boreholes were completed in both locations and handed over to the communities. Training to maintain and repair the boreholes was provided to community members.
